In France, voting is traditionally a low-tech experience: Voters isolate themselves in a booth and stick a pre-printed ballot paper, on which the candidate of their choice is listed, into an envelope.

The French electoral law lays down the procedure quite strictly.

Since 1988, ballot boxes must be transparent so that voters and observers can attest that there are no pre-marked ballots at the beginning of the election and that no pre-marked ballots are cast, except those of the properly counted and authorized voters.

When a small group of organisms (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it came (for example, if they migrate over a mountain range or across a river, or if they colonize a new island, so that they cannot easily return), they often find themselves in a different environment than before.

This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so the new population needs different characteristics or adaptations to be a strong competitor, rather than what it needed before.
The original population has not changed at all. They still need the same adjustments as before.
Over time, the new population adapts to its new environment, and then it looks less and less like the other population.
After thousands or even millions of years two populations may look so different that they cannot be assigned to the same species.
We call this process speciation, which simply means the emergence of new species. Speciation is an unavoidable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, from the technological push or the technological imperative to the strict sense that human destiny is determined by a logic that is linked to scientific laws and its manifestation in technology.

Most interpretations of technological determinism share two general views. One, that the development of technology follows a path that is largely outside of cultural or political influence, and two, that technology itself has effects on societies that are more inherent than socially determined.
One could say that the automobile is unavoidably linked to the development of roads.
However, a national road network for only a small number of cars is not economically viable. Therefore, new production methods are being developed to reduce the cost of car ownership.
The widespread ownership of cars also leads to a higher number of accidents on the roads, which in turn leads to the invention of new techniques in the health sector to repair damaged bodies.

After his farewell by the Congress on July 4, a handwritten, signed by the President of the Congress John Hancock and the Secretary Charles Thomson, was sent a few blocks away to the printing house of John Dunlap.
During the night, between 150 and 200 copies were made, which are now known as the "Dunlap broadsides".
The first public reading of the document was given by John Nixon in the Independence Hall courtyard on July 8.
One was sent to George Washington on July 6, which he read to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy reached London on August 10.
Of the 25 Dunlap broadsides that still exist, they are the oldest surviving copies of the document. The original handwritten document has not survived the ages.

Excursions are an important part of every school class. Not infrequently a teacher would like to take her pupils to places where a bus trip is not an option.
Virtual excursions are a technological solution. Students can view museum exhibits from their classroom, visit an aquarium, or admire works of art.
Sharing a virtual excursion is also a great way to reflect on a trip and share experiences with future classes.

For example, students at the Bennet School in North Carolina design a website every year about their trip to the state capital. The website is redesigned every year, but the previous versions remain online and serve as a scrapbook.

Blogs can also help to improve the writing skills of students. Although students at the beginning of their blogging experience often have a sloppy grammar and spelling, this usually changes when there is an audience.
As students are often a very critical audience, the blog author makes an effort to improve his writing style to avoid criticism.
Blogging "forces students to learn more about the world around them." The need to attract an audience inspires students to write cleverly and interestingly (Toto, 2004).
Blogging is a tool that inspires cooperation and encourages students to continue learning outside the traditional school day.

The appropriate use of blogs can enable students to become more analytical and critical; by reacting to Internet materials, students can define their positions in the context of the texts of others and express their own perspectives on certain topics. (Oravec, 2002)

The Portuguese destroyed them and rebuilt them under the name Casa Branca only to abandon them after an earthquake in 1755.
The Moroccan Sultan rebuilt the city as Dar el Beida and it was called Casablanca by Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.

Goma is a tourist town of the Democratic Republic of the Congo in the extreme east near Rwanda.

While Goma is relatively safe, every stay outside of Goma should be carefully planned in order to find out about the ongoing fighting in the province of North-Kivu.
The city is also the starting point for climbing the volcano Nyiragongo as well as for some of the cheapest gorilla-tracking tours in Africa.

The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in the northeastern part of South Africa. It borders Mozambique in the east, Zimbabwe in the north and the Crocodile River in the south.
The park has an area of 19,500 km2 and is divided into 14 different ecosystems, each supporting a different animal population.
It is one of the main attractions of South Africa and is regarded as the flagship of the South African National Parks (SANParks).
Like all South African national parks, the park charges daily entrance and conservation fees.
It may also be worth buying a Wild Card, which gives access either to selected parks in South Africa or to all South African national parks.

The Sundarbans are the largest mangrove forest in the world and stretch 80 km from the Bangladeshi and Indian hinterland to the coast.
The Sundarbans were designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The part of the forest within the Indian state is called Sundarbans National Park.
The forests are not only mangrove swamps – they also include some of the last remaining stands of the mighty jungle that once covered the Ganges plain.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km2, of which a third is covered by water and marshes.
The Sundarbans have been a nature reserve since 1966, and according to estimates there are now 400 Bengal tigers and about 30,000 spotted deer living there.

The Oyapock River Bridge is a cable-stayed bridge. It spans the Oyapock River and connects the cities of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges de l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
Their two towers are 83 m high, their length is 378 m and they have two lanes with a width of 3.50 m.
The clearance under the bridge is 15 metres. The construction work was completed in August 2011, but the opening to traffic was not until March 2017.
The bridge is expected to be fully operational by September 2017. It is expected that the Brazilian customs checkpoints will be completed by then.
The Guaraní were the most important indigenous group inhabiting the eastern part of Paraguay. They were semi-nomadic hunter-gatherers who also practised subsistence agriculture.
The Chaco region was also home to other groups of indigenous tribes, such as the Guaycurú and the Payaguá, who survived by hunting, gathering and fishing.
Paraguay, formerly known as the Great Province of the West Indies, was created in the 16th century as a result of the meeting of the Spanish conquerors with the indigenous groups.

The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Pound (FKP), which is pegged to the value of the British Pound (GBP).
Money can only be exchanged in the only bank on the island, which is opposite the FIC West Store in Stanley.
The British pound is generally accepted everywhere on the islands and at Stanley credit cards. US dollars are often accepted.

Credit cards are unlikely to be accepted on the more remote islands, but British and U.S. currency will probably be accepted; check with the owners in advance to find out which payment method they accept.
It is almost impossible to exchange the currency of the Falkland Islands outside the islands themselves, so you should exchange your money before you leave the islands.

Stirrups are aids for the feet of riders, which hang down on both sides of the saddle.
They give the rider more stability, but there are safety concerns because the rider's feet might get caught in them.
If a rider falls off their horse and gets caught by the stirrup, they can be dragged along if the horse runs on. To minimise this risk, a number of safety measures can be taken.
First of all, most riders wear riding boots with a heel and a narrow, smooth sole.
